Daniel Boorstin
[letterhead]
THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO  CHICAO 37 - ILLINOIS  DEPARTMENT OF HISTORY  1126 EAST 59TH STREET
May 29, 1963
Dear Jack:

  Many thanks for your Midland Humor and The Disinherited both of which I'm delighted to have, and especially from you.   When I asked you to let me see the Midland Humor I had no idea that you would send me a copy for my own.   It is a book I wanted and I'll promise to put it to good use.

Ruth and I are both specially please to have your "newly disinterred tome" - The Disinherited which seems to have created some stir in its second coming.
  I  hope we can meet again before too long.  Spoke to Dick ?Damon? on the pone the other day and gave him your greetings.  We both so much enjoyed meeting you at the ?Solomon's?
  Let's keep in touch.  Yours, Dan

letterhead  NOVY MIR RUSSIAN WEEKLY  35 EAST 12th STREET  NEW YORK, N.Y.   Tel. ALgonquin 4-1257
July 13, 1932
Dear Comrade Conroy:
Enclosed are verses by a young worker who recently became interested in the revolutionary movement.
Please publish it (with necessary corrections). If not suitable please give reasons and advise the writer.
His address is:
Steve Hart
c/o N. Kolodko
11 S. Tremont
Kansas City, Kansas
Fraternally yours
B. Borisov   Ed. "N. M".

Greetings...
from our house
to your house
Ben and Gertrude Botkins in Croton
Dorothy at the U. of California
Danny at the U. of Rochester

Postcard    
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 S. Green 
Chicago
Illinois
4/26/58 Here we are in the hotbed of temperance - and the Cafeteria is the best in town. Gertrude & I are working at the Library of Congress on Civil War Folklore (including Lincoln) the new plan of which I meant to write you and shall when I return in May. Best wishes to both of you. Ben

10-25-69 AIR MAIL
Dear Jack & Gladys,
How are you! — Arrived here yesterday after 6 days in London.  Having an even better time than last year — We're spending roughly a week also in Vienna, Rome, & Madrid. We get tour rates (hotel & trans.) but we're on our own. Saw Victor Hugo's hse yesterday.
Love, Joe & Lu Bougere
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Missouri
65270  
U.S.A.

Oct. 7 1971
Dear Folks,
Visiting Rome for the 3rd time. Was to go last year — but had a mild heart attack + doc forbade.
Joe + Lu Bougere
Jack + Gladys Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo.
U.S.A.

10-12-72       PAR AVION
Dear Jack + Gladys, 
I guess they just can't keep us down on the farm. 
We are enjoying Paris as always. Le Drugstore burned down about 2 days ago. 
Love Joe + Lu Bougere
Mr. + Mrs Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Missouri
65270
U.S.A.

Dear Jack + Gladys,
Having the old European fling again. Thought we'd look at this delightfully wicked "Maniac" again.
Joe + Lu Bougere
Mr. + Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Missouri
65270
U.S.A.

3-10-75
Dear Jack + Gladys, 
We've been here in Europe since Jan. 22 — I retired on Jan 17. We plan to be here a year. Next back to Rome, + then Athens, Cairo, Istanbul, etc.
Love, Joe + Lu Bougere.

Here's where Savonarola got his — couldn't keep quiet!
Mr + Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave
Moberly, Missouri 65270
U.S.A.

The University of Chicage
Chicago 37 * Illinois
The College
Feb 12, 50
Dear Jack:
I ought to let you think that my
absense on the night of January 21 was due
to your snide remark about my lending "refine-
ment" to the affair. Actually, I was reclining
on  my shoulder-blades in Billings with an
advanced case of virus pneumonia which had
be laid out for nearly a month. I was sorry
to miss it: I haven't seen you for years and
should have liked to see what ravages root-
beer has wrought with your system in the
interim. Count me in on the next deal, will
you?
If you have been brought up on a 
picture of academic life as "quiet" and "untroubled",
you have litte idea of my daily round. As Diggles
may have told you, I am trying to teach, advise,
get my Ph.D., & avoid being trampled by my offspring
-- all at the same time. As a result, I don't 
get around much anymore. But I intend to have
a hell of an abandoned old age. Let's hope we
get together before then. Regards to Nelson, if 
you see him. Wright, I hear, is playing Bigger
in a Buenos Aires filming of N.S.
Regards,
Merlin
- By the way, our boys have greatly
enjoyed both Slappy Hooper & The Fast Sooner Hound.
When are you putting out another?

[image]
Jeffery, Ruth, Merlin, + John
Bowen
Merry Christmas
Happy New Year
(over)

Shimer College
Mt. Carroll, Ill.
Dee. 21, 1951
Dear Jack:
Many thanks for your note + the minatory tracts. Ruthie's busy letting all her hems down, so I'll have to write this.
Our boys have enjoyed your Slappy Hooper + the Fast Sooner Hound — though we got them (deadbeats that we are) from the public library. They were really very nice jobs, though you had spoiled the Hound for me by telling me the original story once; the present version is — what shall I say? "Watered down" hardly seems the correct word. We'll look for Sam Patch and, in time, for Little Big Shorty. If the Univ. comes through with a raise, I may even buy a copy.
Say hello to Nelson, + write again.
— Merlin

[postcard]    [in pencil at top:  Bowen, Merlin]
Bowen  5728 Drexel Ave.  Chicago  37, Ill  
(Very) Rev. Jack Conroy    14626 Millard Avenue  Midlothian Illinois
[postmark]  Chicago  Apr 26 4:30 PM  1960  ILL

April 26, '60
Dear Jack:
Diggles had relayed your
kind offer & I was all set
to phone you when we got the
news of my appt. as Fulbright
lecturer at Athens for next year
& I took off to the ionosphere
like a Redstone missle & forgot
everything - Anyway, thanks!
A review copy is enroute. For
some obscure reason (a slip up, 
they say) the Press had sent
none to the Sun-Times, so I'll
appreciate it if you can get 
me a ¶ there too. - In return
I shall certainly watch for Hill &
Wang ballots & cast forty or so
ballots for The Disinherited which
by all means needs to be in print.

 You may wish to pass the word

along in literary circles that I
am scheduled to address a
learned society (in the Union 
League Club, no less!) next month
on the topic: "Some Little-Known
Limericks of Ella Wheeler Wilcox."
- By the way, I was amused to see
Mark Harris' tribute to you in Wake
Up, Stupid! - Yours, Merlin

[Postcard]    [in pencil at top:  Bowen, Merlin]
Jack Conroy
Editorial Dept.
Standard Education Society, Inc.
130 N. Wells St
Chicago 6
Illinois

[postmark]
Chicago  Oct 11  10 PM  1961

Wed.
Dear Jack -
Taking my cue from
H.L.M., I answer your
last on the day of its
reception. Many thanks
for the enclosures. The 
TLS clips, your reviews
(the O'Connor autobiog sounds
especially good) and the
beautiful tracts. The
sheep number is one of
the best, don't you think?
The one on White-Slaving
in 10 Easy Lessons looks
good but I haven't yet
read it. - I haven't heard
of the Diggles Orgy as yet;
probably I haven't given up
the right things to get in
on this particular blast.
We'll meet somewhere, though.
Thanks again,
- MB
[Image of city showing city walls, steps, people at market stall]

Taxco: Jan 4, 65
Dear Jack -
Thanks for the Xmas card.
Your skip trace service was
better than mine: I had no idea
where to find you - Missouri? Ireland?
Mid Nothiam? Anyway, muy picante
greetings to you & Gladys
from both of us. The tracts
are wonderul: I'll have
them translated & posted in
the local pulauereas.
We leave in 2 days for
Ozxaca where I'll look
up your friend Russlee Ames.
Is he a writer or a designer
of pottery or what? The name 
is familiar.
yrs,
Merlin

Jack Conroy
7027 S. Jeffery Blvd
Chicago, Ill
60649
U.S.A.

1 April 70
Dear Conray
Not time for a letter:
too many papers etx. stacked
up during the MacGonagall
Sesquicentennial.
But here is the pciture
of yuo two at Grampa's
Park - little the worse
for having been in my camera
all winter.
Walter Evans (now in 
my Melville seminar) was
really set up by the chance
to meet you. He had
been very timid and was
afraid you wouldn't want
to be intruded on. You have
another academic fan there.
- Yours
Merlin

9 Dec. 69
Dear Jack:
Your Xmas note arrived just as
I was sacking up the enclosed Zeroxes
from my final exam to send you.
About 5 of my 30 students chose to use
The Disinherited  as one of the novel for their
exam questiion. You may be interested
to know that the book was very well
received (respectfully, if you will let
me use that word) as a record of experience
in an age that seems to most
of them as distant and the Civil War. In class
disccussion, they were struck by the book's
honesty and forse but coming to it after
the complexities of Dow Passos & Faulkner
were puzzled to know how to talk about
it in terms of technique, etc. One bright 
but somewhat schematic student attacked 
it as "too naive" & failing to present a
coherent & convincing development of Larry's
change to policial activisim. He was
jumped on by others, one of them accusing
him of wanting a different book than
the one the author intended & urging
him to "write it yourself" - I kept the
stinger - that I knew the author - 
until after discussion, incidentally.
Native Son made quite an impact,
too, coming as it did just at the 
time of the Cop's killing of the

Black Panthers on our West Side.
Re-reading N.S. for the first time
in 30 years was something
of a shocker for me, too: I was 
reminded all over again of my
amazement of 1940 that so
much pent-up voilence could
underlie such gentleness. I
have his Outsider now & will
try it when course preparation
leaves me time.

  The photos of you and Gladys

are still in the camera,
waiting until our drab winter
world produces something
colorful enough to justify
being on the same roll of film.
I'll send a print eventually.

  Must break off now &

head for O'Hare: I've
got to go to the College Boards
in Atlantic City to earn enough
to pay my income tax.

  Consider yourself & Gladys

seasonally & seasonably greeted.
Merlin 
(Bowen)

Bucharest: 21 Nov
Dear Jack + Gladys -
Your note of 29 Oct deserves
more than this card but we
are in the midst of getting ready
to ship Ruthie home for the first
wedding in the family since our
own: Jeff, our #2 boy, is getting 
married - most inconveniently for
us - in Dec. + since I can't
get away from classes, she is
going to hold up our end. I'll
be living on Momaliga (oat meal 
mush) for a month till she returns.
By all means ship the ABC issue
to me, this address, domestic rates.
Sounds interesting.
Teaching here is a bit discouraging.
My courses, I learn, are
required but "not for credit" + without
exam or paper. The result, of 
course, is that it's impossible
to get them to reay anything - Moby=-Dick
or The Disinherited. But I'll tell
them the story of each, if you +
Merman can be satisifed w/that.
All's quiet here: no debauchery,
though some good music + scads
of theater - all, alas! in Romanien:
8 Repertory companies in Bacherest.
Chicago can't manage one! - Regards,
MB

MERLIN BOWEN
5515 WOODLAWN AVENUE
CHICAGO, ILLINOIS 60637
JACK CONROY
701 FISK AVENUE
MOBERTY
MISSOURI
65270
thought he can't really
accept it. Short + cheerful
notes are the best.
- Merlin

Nov. 5, 1972 
Dear Jack and Gladys -
A last note before the long Nixon Night settles over us. Thanks for your Oct 31 letter w enclosures. I missed the reviews of the NP book, since I almost never look at a newspaper. (Too painful.) Will watch for the Wright and Conroy issues of New Letters, though. Have been meaning to get Peg Weschude and will after your reminder. - The serious part of this message is to tell you that Wiggles is in extremely bad shape, emotionally and physically. His long ago melancholia has come over him again. He is unable to read or to see anyone for more than a few minutes. He is hospitalized, but write him at home in assumed ignorance of his condition. He won't answer, but Mary will read you letter to him and it will be appreciated. He needs contact

Merlin Bowen!
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly 
Missouri 65270
P.S.  I dont think you even read the books! - Maybelle M.

Chicago Ill
Dec 7, 72
Dear Mr Conoray:
It seemed to me that you might be helped to write better book-revues if you was to study the rules sat down by Belly Swords (incosed) also rites revued for [ARE?] NRTA (National Journal Retired Teachers Assoc.)Betty's are real good, not

like the shit you turn out in the Chicago Sun-Times.
So study these rules!
With all joy full wishes for Xmas,
yore friend,
Maybelle
Mulligan
(age 92)
Postcard image of Paul Gauguin's "The Big Tree"]

Chicago: Dec,20,72
Dear Conroys
Greetings of this dismal season! Deck [ Hanoi?] with bombs and Napal, tra, la, la, la, la...! Makes me wonder if the N. Vietnamese knows the dangers of cigarettes. Should NN send then a missionary?
Diggles is better. Like you + me; his problems remain- but he is coping again. His occasional packet of nonsense will help though.
Speaking of nonsense, did some crazy female name of Mulligan get in touch w you? She was pestering me on the phone for your address +seemed sore about some review of yours.- {Mich?] I don't know & she was an outraged author? fairly incoherent. Regards, The Bowens
Jack + Gladys Conroy
701 Frisk St.
Maberly
Missouri
65270

Kohinata 2-13-15
Bunkyp-ku, Tokyo 112
April 12, 1928
Dear friends: I'm getting too old to emulate trich but it's fun to watch others.
Japan is glowing with satisfaction that Jack Conroy has had some cash laid on him to write his autobiography. We glow + rejoice too. Floreat Conroy!
We've moved into the world's 2nd largest city (1st? Mexico City!) for our last 4 months. _The Walshes will be here for 3 weeks in May + June and we'll continue the party they held in your honor in Pak Park._ Gladys are you keeping up the hymn singing? And do you have an anti- cigarette [baflets?] for Buddhists in Japanese, Jack?
-Best wishes, the Bowens
Jack +Galdys Conroy 
701 Frisk Avenue
Moberly
Missouri
U.S.A.
652-70

Dear friends-
A short note to wish you both a mild winter low water, and good health.
Things are as well here as can be expected by a couple of our venerable years.
Our friend + former Colleague on the Project, Nate Morres, died about 10 days ago. Frank + Betty Walsh are putting up with their oilments (F.O.'s poor vision and Betty's broken collar bone and bruises from a God tumble down their back stairs). All the best to you M B
Season's Greetings from Ruth + Merlin
Bower
Jack + Gladys Conroy
701 Frisk Ave.
Moberly
Mo. 65270

Sept. 10, 1980
Bowen, Merlin
Dear Jack (crossed) Moberly Dick:   
Glad to hear that Gladys is home from the hospital + getting her strength back. When will she rejoin the Methodist Choir? Many thanks for shipping the Reader off to [Ohasbi?] complete with inscription. He'll probably stage an exhibition at the Imperial Palace. Are you available for autographing? A few days ago we partied at Walshes to send Mary Diggles off to her new bride-groom , one Olof Suen Frosman of Bitrch Harbor, Maine. Wedding on Sept 21st. We'll miss it because we have in another day or so for a month in Nova Scotia, but will see them we hope in Maine on our way back. He's a lapsed Lutheran + she an earnest Catholic but these being ecumenical times, they're having the knot tied in a Catholic church. What would Luther say? Do you know where I could get a copy of Slappy Hooper or The Fast Sooner Hound for our grandsons?
All the best to you both Merlin

Chicago, Ill. 60637
5515 Woodlawn Ave
April 23, 1981
Dear Jack and Gladys-
Today _ Shakespeare's birthday is the day of my annual desk-cleaning_ and I have found your long lost card! I hasten to write you (evelosing a $9.00 check) to cover cost + postage for an autographed copy The Fast Sooner Hound to be sent to our grandsons:
Sean and Joshua Bowen
28 Wilworth Crescent
Toronto, Ont M4K1Z6 Canada
We will be passing through there in two more weeks en route to Maine, and I hope to have the pleasure of reading it to them -inscription + all.- We will be going for a 6-wk stay in Birch Harbor, Maine, as cat + house sitters for Mary Diggles Forsmark and her new husband Olof Sven Forsmark while they are in Sweden meeting Mary's new inlaws.
Ruth + I are tol'ably well. How about yourself and Gladys?
A postcard would be welcome
all the best 
Merlin

Birch Harbor, ME
May 17,81
Dear Jack-
We pulled in here on the 12th to cat-sit for Mary W. Forsmark + Olof and were handed the N.Y. Sunday Times Obit page with this account of Nelson's exit. Since you may not see the Times, I send it along. We are to be here guarding their estate for another 4 weeks or so until they return from Europe. Until this afternoon the weather has been cold, foggy, + wet, but we hope for better luck- unless sun brings out the infamous black flies. In any event, we can't desert our post or even reclaim our own place, now occupied bu a Japanese academic family!, before June 28th.
Mary seems to have made a successful metamorphosis from a metropolitan lady of fashion to an end-of-the-road waterside retiree. She and Olof  - a quiet, easygoing Swedish artist of about my age (70=)_ seem to hit it off well. We like him very much.
There was a letter from Ohashi, your Tokyo representative waiting for us here. He says you or Fred Whitehead got him the address of the Wobblies' publisher- something in which I had so far failed him: they had apparently gone underground from their middle-north Chicago spot.
Mary also spoke of you and Gladys warmly so I guess my identification of Olof (above) was unnecessary. Ruth and I hope that Gladys is feeling better by now and that your own rugged health holds up. Give Gladys our love + best wishes.- And yourself too.
Merlin + Ruth
Did you get my earlier note + check about The Fast Sooner Hound?.- Let ir ride a while if other things are more pressing.

May 26, 1982
Dear Conroys-
How are things with you? Is it as cold and wet down there as it is here? We spent a month- mid April to mid- May in New Mexico with relatives in Albuquerque = those parts and haven't yet adjusted to life in the frozen North. and in another ten days we will move farther North still- to Toronto for a visit with Jeff's family.
I'm not doing much of importance these days. (Was I ever? I forget.) In the winter quarter I taught one course, and a week ago I finished reading galley proofs on a fairly long article on A Passage to India that is to appear in the August issue of Modern Philology, a journal I'm sure you await eagerly, issue by issue. Joe Carroll (Do you remember him, Jack?) has had a short Joycean play, "Mr Bloom = the Cyclops,"produced by Joe Papp in NYC. So we septuagenarians manage to cotter to the typewriter now + then despite seen the Walshes for some 6 weeks or more but they seem to be doing well. Frank writes a weekly column for an Oak Park paper, Betty gardens, and both have a flock of grandchildren to keep them occupied. They'll celebrate a 43rd anniversary soon- nearly two years ahead of us.

No recent word from Mary Wiggles. Meanwhile our social life centers upon visiting Japanese, for whom our apt has become a station on the undeground railway.. We enjoy it: They were very good to us over there + we're happy yo return the hospitality when we can.
Ohashi - your Tokyo fan, Jack- is well but involved in settling his Conroy Collection in the new house he has recently built there. He asks of you when he writes, which is less frequently these days. When you have time, send us a card with news of yourselves to pass on to him.
All the best,
Merlin

5515 Woodlawn Ave.
Chicago, Ill 60637
Jan 13, '83
Dear Jack:
Although I had known of Gladys' long illness I learned of her death only recently from Mary W. Forsmark who forwarded your Xmas card to her in a letter to us. I never knew Gladys as well as I did you, but I liked what I knew and I can well imagine how much you must miss her. Time is catching up with many of us. I believe I told you of Nate Morris's recent death. Betty Walsh is rallying from some very extensive surgery from stomach cancer. (She knows it and speaks of it, but if you write them better let them tell you the nature of the surgery.). Fortunately, the prognosis is as good as it can be in such a case: no trace of spread to lymphatic system or liver. Ruthie and I find our several small illnesses hanging on- most probably terminal in the sense that we'll never be permanently free of them- but we manage to go about our daily business when we can remember what it is. The impediments of life is what gives us most trouble; so many little decisions about what to throw out, what we can live without etc. At an age

when life should be getting simplified of the large clear Sophoclean outlines, one's indecisions involve us in trivialities. I have cancelled out on an invitation to teach a Conrad seminar in the Spring; Why (much as i love Conrad) trudge around the same old course one more time and do it worse? The few hundred bucks I would get would make little difference financially, and the possibility exists- theoretically- that I might pull myself together enough to write a little book for the grandsons. But how can I hope to follow so successful and act as your Fast Sooner Hound? (see enclosed photo of three dedicated Conroy scholars; Sean of the right, Joshua on the left, Cap'n Peleg in the middle.) It was good of you, Jack, to send the boys a card; it's taped to their wall now in Toronto.
Well, I'll sign off for now, and wish for all the best for you in '83.- Do you pla to get back at the memoir now that you have more freedom?
Ruth says to greet you for her
Affectionately,
Merlin

[upper right corner:] Bowen, Merlin
May 25, 1984
Dear Jack:
Walsh received an invitation to the big Catfish Fry that the Univ. of Missouri is -- somewhat belatedly -- holding for you next month. Somehow  I was left off the official list -- though I couldn't have come anyway, for reasons soon to be s stated. But could you see that the sponsoring committee sends a packet of praise for the Sage of Moberly to your devoted Japanese fan, Prof. Kiteh Ohashi, Dept. of English, Keio University, Mita, Tokyo? He will really appreciate it. Walsh was going to bring his invite to the Goodman play he and I were attending yesterday -- but he forgot. He and I are both on tight leashes these days with ailing wives. Betty has been laid up for some months now and seems to be getting no better. Ruth and her visiting nurse sister Beth (with us until tomorrow) made Betty's favorite dessert this morning and were going out to Oak Park to deliver

it, but at the last moment Frank called to say Betty was worse and not to come.
Now a line or two for Ruth's trouble, most of which is now in the past. On May 7th she had a job of heavy surgery aimed at what was mistakenly thought to be lung cancer. A 4-hour operation brought forth a large but benign tumor on the vagus nerve, hidden away behind lung, heart, etc. & next to the spine -- a spot unreachable by the biopsy needle. They damned near cut her in two but she is slowly coming around and in another two weeks sill be back in harness.
Have I written you that we're due to go back to Japan for a couple of months in the fall for some lectures at Meiji Univ.? And next spring I'm signed up as a sub for the Chicago English dept as the only ambulatory American lit man they will have available that quarter. All the rest have grants and fellowships abroad. Hope I can make it until then.
Congratulations, Jack and best wishes! Walsh plans to write you.
-- Merlin Bowen

Dear friends-
-Just saw Bradley's column in Panorama. First we knew of your back to nature program. We'll try yo chart a trip through Moberly some day.
Best wishes from us both.
- Merlin

8-25-85
[far left corner] latest stamp in Regan's series of Great Radical Writers of America
Dear Jack-
have sent you several cards + notes in recent years, but without answers. Now today's Trib Book Page has a good revs of your Need KIng [?]. Congrats!- I'll get a copy, read it and send it on to your Japanese fan, Prof. Ohashi, for his collection. 
Do you remember Frank Walsh in Oak Park? He lost his wife (to cancer) early this spring, but is otherwise well. I'll call the Trib review to his attention.
Ruth and I send you our love.
-Merlin
At 86, you're even older than me, who was 76 3 wks ago.
-Even Nostalgia ain't what it sued to was!
[left side]
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly
Mo.
65270

My dear Jack Conroy:

             Asending to Art Church you know about the anthology,                                                    For 

but es homs you will let me thank you reailim to it. Cordially,                                                           Mr. Jack Conroy
Marjoirie Peleak                                                                                                                              Edelinal Department
(Mrs. Philip Bower)                                                                                                                        Standard Education - Savely
Plaza 57445 Harper                                                                                                                       130 N. Wells at Chicago 
2-8377      Cheron.

BETRENIA WATT
997 BENTON AVENUE, SPRINGFIELD, MISSOURI
My dear broken-ribbed-one,
At this late date you may be no longer [riding?] the bed, but Jean's letter informing me of the accident didn't arrive until the middle of last last week- & what with Thanksgiving! I'm glad that you weren't injured more seriously & I hope the unclear is healed.
How did the trip- other than the frustrated unclear driven angle- go? Was anyone convinced that what this country needs is freedom of speech & press?
It- I'm still talking about The trip- brought 13 unclear unclear to St. Louis unclear.
I'd like to get up to the old stomping ground this

weekend if possible & see the play "Bury the Dead", (among other things) but I don't know if I can make it.
Despite the fact that you received no acknowledgment of it, I did get your letter about the things for the unclear unclear for considering mine.
Well, take care of your unclear, Jack, & beware of Santa Claus. He has a long beard & wears a conical cap.
Betrenia
Harry Browning asks that I tell you your "World to Win" is very fine. Excellent, in fact. And as good or better than anything John Dos Passos has written. If I didn't agree with that last comment, I'd pretend I didn't know you the next time I see you.
I just reread "Life With Father" last evening & enjoyed it as heartily as the other times I read it.
B.W.

CHICAGO DAILY NEWS
AN INDPENDENT NEWSPAPPER FOUNDED JANUARY 1, 1876
Jack-
Good to hear from you-
Hope you can do this for me-
Best-
Van
VAN ALLEN BRADLEY

[Image:  woman's head and shoulders; hair wrapped in towel; shower head]
Virgo

[in pencil in upper margin]  Brady, Kristin

27 November 1983
Dear Jack,
We know that Virgo isn't your sign, but we decided to send you this card anyway.
Happy Birthday next week!
We had a visit from Jahava during the summer. She is as feisty as ever, and her book is getting good reviews.
We hope you are well and that you have a pleasant new year.
-Kristin & Avrum

[in pencil in upper margin]  (no date)  Brady, Kristin
again passing through Moberly.    In fact, if we are in that part of the country again, we will make you the reason for a trip to Moberly.
Yours sincerely,
Kristin Brady 
&
Avrum Fenson
(some of your visitors from "outer space")

[Image:  front of postcard]
Florida Cypress Gardens
The Singing Tower
Happiness in Florida
There is happiness in Florida
You find it everywhere,
It seems to flow around you
Like sunshine in the air,
I do not know from whence it comes,
But this I surely know,
In Florida, true happiness
I find where'er I go.
Hilda Towse

[back of postcard]  [in pencil in top margin:]  Fenson, Avnum
APT 202, 780 VISCOUNT RD LONDON, ONTARIO, CANADA N61 3T3

Dear Jack:
I am a bit amused at your evident compact with Kathryn to give you my address the moment she had it; but I trust you were properly reticent, for your self-respect and mine. Nothing else is amusing; bafflement and dismay do not focus into clarity. I have written three letters tonight, to trace what happened to my little nest-egg and to illuminate like matters.
In the ordinary writing of a check, the Spitzer-Rorick Trust & Savings Bank of Toledo would have been my assignee. But my account there is a "Chexcel" account -- i.e., as you doubtless know, you buy a block of checks, at 7½ ¢ ea., each with your own printed name and your Chexcel number. I discovered that I had run out of Chexcels, and bethought myself of my nest-egg. Now I do not know.
What I do know is that it is incredible that I should wish to defraud one I esteem as much as I do you. I ask your patience until I straighten this thing out. Your $60 (plus $5, you may remember) is safe, even if my memory is at fault and I have to cash in my insurance to redress the balance.
Cheerful postscript: my typewriter was stolen last week.
Yours, Douglas

June 21 - 1935
Dear Jack Conroy
Your note of appreciation of the "Nation" review was sent to me here, and pleased me very much. About the first title I could read easily in a Leningrad bookshop was The Disinherited - and I've seen it lots of times in Moscow in the shops that have foreign books. This is the place to come to help one to venture into the affirmative + picture the world to be won.

places where recreation was going on: tennis courts, ball fields, a place for acrobatics - but socially the theatre where fine folk dancing was going on -- the concert room, where 40 or 50 young men + women were doing choral singing unclear Russians can do it -- another music room where an orchestra --  a brass brand rather -- was rehearsing some music from "Prince Igor." and there was so much vitality + happiness in all these activities that it gave one those chills up + down the spine to watch it all, + try to realize its significance for the future + its relation to the whole society of which it is a part. Anyone can leave the commune who wants to -- there are no quads or malls -- only they

My demand, as reader + critic, upon our own proletarian fiction, to picture that world is going to be more exacting than ever, now that I've had a glimpse of its possibilities here. Ah Bolshevo?, for instance, that famous commune that started ten years ago with a group of the homeless boys; + has continued with additions of thieves and safe-crackers -- until now it is a flourishing community with its school, foundry, wood work shop, textile mill, clinic,

don't want to! Tis only a glimpse one can get in a few weeks, but it helps. I mentioned Bolshevo just because it was the latest thing I've seen.

I'll hope to see you in the fall in New York. My best wishes for your work.

Cordially
Dorothy Brewster

Dear Jack Conroy:
It is nice to hear from you again. Yes, Mr. Meine? wrote to me about doing a revised Joyce, unclear, + James for the rejuvenated Nelson's, + I have written that I would.
In spite of my almost prehistoric St. Louis origin, I can't seem to come across with any suggestions for your humorous collection - My reading has been on the heavy side for a long time, and in my spare time I've struggled again with the Russian language - I got to the U.S.S.R. again last summer -- having

interested VOKS (Society for Cultural Relations) enough in a projected study on Russian influences on English literature to be rated a visa--and when I arrived in Leningrad, to be received as a guest and entertained for six weeks. It was quite a nice experience. Now, more than ever before, I feel I must write the book--if only to justify my entertainment. So that is what I'm trying to put through, & it will take some months yet of research. As Columbia is experiencing a boom in students, and all classes including mine are unreasonably large, I have very little spare time for the library work--
I've noted down the name of your folk take "Slappy Hooper"--I have two or three small friends--& maybe it will be suitable for one of them--Best of luck in your enterprises---
Cordially
Dorothy Brewster

January 24, 1966
Dear Jack Conroy--
Thank you for two recent letters (Jan. 10 and 18), with the enclosure of the review of my book. I am not familiar with any of these papers and magazines you mention, & am not likely to see or hear of any reviews. My subscription to a Clipping service ran out several years ago & I didn't think it worth while to spend any money on renewals. It is just as well. When I was teaching & lecturing I kept up with the books connected with my subjects--the reviews in the Times Literary Supplement, the PMLA, Nation, New Statesman-Sat. Review etc.

Sounds disgustingly highbrow--doesn't it? Years ago I had a small list of favorite reviewers, who were really helpful--Do you remember the late Robert Morss Lovett?  & there was the still flourishing Joseph Wood Krutch, my colleague at Columbia, who retired to the Arizona desert some years ago, & does beautiful books on wild life & the balance of nature, & so on. About all I read nowadays is the Herald-Trib-BookWeek-the Nation-The American Scholar-now & then the Saturday Review & the New Statesman. But I do remember that some of the most intelligent reviews of books I have written came from newspapers here & there through the country, &, in England, provincial papers.
The review you sent me aroused the reflection--rather usual, after reading book reviews--that the reviewer hadn't read the book. He

accused me of going off the track in ascribing to Virginia Woolf an influence on Doris Lessing. I did nothing of the sort--I made some comparisons. 
Several of my friends, whose critical judgment I value, have said intelligent things about my books, & I am pretty well satisfied with that! I am not at all sure that, as you say, any notice is better than none--But don't let me deter you from wanting notices! I liked your review of Farrell's book very much--
I'm glad your novel--They Seek a City--is being revised & republished--& most happy that The Disinherited is having a continental sale. Those Seven Seas books--I have seen quite a few of them in London--
By the way Arnold Wesker's new play, "Their Very Own Golden City" is to be

produced next May at the Royal Court in London--The title reminds me of They Seek a City. In this play, he is seeking a City, too. I read the unrevised version this summer--It needed a good deal of revision, but it is a fascinating subject. You would have found Arnold a very interesting person to meet. The book in the Twayne series of English Authors, on Arnold Weeks (no. 28)--has just come out. By someone I don't know, Ribalow. Maybe you will see it. 
I did ask Twayne to send you a copy of Doris Lessing.
This is a rather rambling letter--Please remember me to Gladys, my fellow Missourian. And thank you for anything you can do to help Doris Lessing along--
Best wishes--
Dorothy Brewster

June 14, 1976
Dear Jack,
These clippings are probably the last I have.  They're the result of still another attempt to go through a more-than-two-year accumulation in our basement.  This time we're in earnest - we must get rid of papers, magazines, books, - to say nothing of all kinds of other things that got relegated to the nether region.   We never throw out - we just take downstairs.

  I say "for real" because we want to put the house up for sale, and right now it wouldn't be "good business" to show prospects a cluttered basement.  Other things need to be done too, but sometime this summer I think we will be ready to be put on the block.
   We'll be heading West - earthquake country.  Our one and only - did I write earlier that our Helen decided to junk her first name in favor of Susan, her second given name? - keeps calling us - and now she and Gary have two children:  Michele is 4½  years old and Steven is 4 months old.   So we'll look for an apartment in their general area - Los Angeles, in the San Fernando Valley.   The kids live in Woodlnad Hills, and we'll try for a neighboring suburb.  (I dread the thought of renting, but see no good alternative.)

I doubt we'll get away before autumn - finding a customer involves luck, I'm sure.

   Have been out of touch with the Standard crew for a  while.  How about you?
   How goes it with you and Gladys - hope you've been keeping well.   Haven't had any report on the status of your memoirs.
   Will you be getting to Chicago?
   I hope these clips will revive memories - all good.
   Ruth joins me in wishing you both the very best.

As ever,
Harry

Dear Gladys & Jack:

   We hope that Gladys has recovered fully, and that both of you are managing to enjoy life.   I am a failure (complete) when it comes to writing these days, and the punishment is being deprived of your delightful notes.  It takes one to get one.
  We were completely surprised and saddened to hear that the very wonderful Giggy has died.  I suppose you have heard.  What a loss!
  Paul Romaine had a

heart operation, and is recovering.

   What are you up to?  We miss the book reviews.  I'll call you one of these days.   Do  you ever get to Chicago?  If you do, we are in the book.

[printed message on Christmas card:  SEASON'S GREETINGS]

Love,

Chicago
Sept. 28, 1981
Dear Jack & Gladys:

  If I don't take care of things right away, they become buried, which is where I'll be before I organize my papers.  You may already  have the clips from another Chicago connection.  Anyway, forgive me.  We hope that Gladys is okay, and that you manage without too much difficulty.
  You aren't missing much in Chicago.  The weather has been excessively rainy and gloomy.   The transportation is deteriorating rapidly (at 90₵ a ride, plus 10₵ a transfer).  Our real estate taxes have gone up 100% (240. per month)
  California, "land of fruit and nuts" gave us Reagan

-2-
(he was REEGAN when I was born), and so much for progress.

   Do you ever see the "Reader"?  It is one of the best references as a weekly, and I am enclosing a marvelous section.
  Jim Peneff is still heading the City News Bureau, and nearing retirement, although he looks very young and lean.
  Paul Romaine is in remarkably good health in spite of serious heart problems.  He said that he would write a postscript to the Bodenheim article to send to the Reader.
  I wish that it were more simple to get to Moberley, but without a car it sounds difficult.
  How are you?  We think of you often.  Our love to both of you.

Sanka

August 25, 1983
Dear Jack,

  Thank you so much for your so-Jack-like letter!  What a pleasure to hear from you.
   You'll understand that all of us here were dismayed when we heard of your loss.  Gladys was a Trooper "The Disinherited" is a Classic FOREVER.  Never doubt it.  And YOU are a classic forever.
  Please get your autobiography out and abroad!  It

will be a magnificent contribution to the world's literature.

   With continued respect, affection, and admiration,

Gwen
P.S.  Yes, it's true, our writing friends are dropping away.   At least a dozen of those I know you'd remember Jack McPhaul, Hope Norris, Hoyt Fuller, George Kent, Robert Hayden, Sarah Webster Fabio.

   But that's to be expected, right?  What's REALLY "dismaying" is the death of so many 40 year-olds.

I See Chicago
Up-chinned, redemptive, obdurate and fond!
I see Chicago leaning toward a light
Indelible, substantial - to unite
Fever and ice in dialogue and bond.
Iron is the will below the flying smile.
Hale is the heart of this rich rebel whose
Scars alter, furies falter and diffuse,
Vagueness reverses, in a little while.
I see Chicago, city of yeast and yield.
City of clangor.
City of lungs and and languor.
City of maul and mercy, city of the out-stuck neck, city of perils repealed,
Already grand, already harvested.
With grander range and grander reach ahead.
Gwendolyn Brooks

May 13, 1935
Dear Jack,

  Thanks for sending the book.   I hd already rented it from our library, liked it so much I bought a copy and am doing my best to circulate it and create a sale here.  Some of the university and Green Dragon sections didn't stack up to either the first or last parts, but you've done a grand job on the whole and certainly there is growth from "The Disinherited."  The climax is magnificent.  I hope every student in my courses will read it on my recommendation.  There is still plenty of Humanism, even Menckenism rampant among the local sensitive souls and the part which I didnt think

was the best as prolet. lit. ought to shake some courage into the wavering esthetes.   The best thing about the book is your own fine verification of your thesis that the lives of common labourers are as authentic literary material as the vicissitudes of society women.  You understate it today as your work with Cantwells, and some of Caldwells shows the workers give more authentic material.  On your Guggenheim why dont you give Hemmingway a push.  The fellow can write better than any of you but his material is growing awfully stale.

  I read  in the papers you are going to travel around America.   If you ever come through here stop a day or so with us.  The work with the students is beginning to [written in left margin] go magnificently.   We have  strong undergraduate committees on peace and racial equality and by next year ought to have some [?].

Nov 25, 1934
Dear Comrade Conroy:

   With the rapid decay of capitalism and associated with this decay a frightful increase in the misery of the workers and small farmers, the danger of fascism and war, etc., impose upon every revolutionary the duty of organizing the masses for struggle against this menace.
    Especially is it of great importance to build groups of CP members in every locality who will guide and direct activities among the masses.
   As a means of spreading our work among the farmers, for example, we must have units in the towns, using these as a base from which to reach out among the farmers.
    Maybe you can assist us in getting in touch with workers and farmers in the Moberly section and also elsewhere in Missouri, who are or can be made good timber for the Party.   We should have a good unit of CP in Moberly.   If you have names and addresses of prospective CP members please send them to me.
    As literature, in preparation for the organization of units, the following

might be given:
The Daily Worker (bundles 1 3/4 c a copy)
The Program of the Communist Intn'l, 10¢.
Leninism - Stalin, 10¢.
The Communist (monthly), 20¢ a copy.
The Intern'l Press Corresp. (weekly), 10¢ a copy
The Communist Intern'l (semi-monthly), 10¢ a copy.
Why Communism? - Olgin, 10¢.

   Above can be ordered from Workers' Library Publisher, Box 148 Station D, New York, N.Y.   Daily Worker is at 50 East 13th St., New York, N.Y.
   Shall be very glad to hear from you at your earliest opportunity.  Through the organization of class conscious, determined groups, such as the CP units, we can carry on many-sided activities.

Fraternally yours,
Frank Brown
℅ John Babbitt  14 ½  N National Ave  Ft. Scott, Kan.
(Note:  Am at the above address for a few days).

November 12, 1963
Dear Jack,
Thanks for sending me the inscribed copy of the Dreiser article. I didn't know that Inland did such a wonderful literary job. The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Bulletin is nothing by comparison. It just isn't a market, although I had a poem in it once for free. I enjoyed meeting Jack. I knew him from A.V., but I didn't know he was your illustrious grandson. I remember with what gusto I consumed the elephantine 
Financier and Titan. I never read The Stoic, but I was amazed to learn when I did read them that Yerkes was the prototype.   I was thinking that Paul Dresser wrote "She's More to Be Pitied Than Censured," but you've

put it in perspective for me. Paul D. did write that Hoosier classic "The Banks of the Wabash," though I also didn't know that Mencken was, in a sense,  Dreiser's protege. I'd thought of Mencken as springing fullblown from the Olympian heights all by himself.   Also, wonder of all wonders, that Mencken ever pleaded with anyone to "remove an offending passage"!

  I'm glad to know that your operation was such a success and that your convalescence was so uneventful, like mine.
  I almost picked up a coy of Dos Passos' U.S.A. trilogy in an antique shop in Knox, Indiana, yesterday, but it

(3
wasn't a first edition and I have the content in the wondrous paperbacks, so I desisted. 
I've lent out your Disinherited to an up-and-coming PhD at 30 with a sharp mind. He is a U. of C. man, but
he may go to the Claremont, California, College as an associate prof.   I'd like to see Midland Humor. 
Grove still has my book - an encouraging sign, but I've come to accept rejection and still come slugging back. After all The Sound and the Fury 
was rejected by 13 publishers.  The Frank Harris book may seem rather tame to the jaded modern

(4
public, but maybe the apocryphal passages will help spur sales. Banning will, of course, made the cash register jingle.  I won an award in the national Scholastic Magazine contest
for high schoolers when I was seventeen for an article on Frank Harris. Little did I know, then,  though about so many of his extracurricular claims to fame. I wrote it straight from finding copies of Pearson's Magazine around my folks' house. My mother still has them; maybe they have commercial value. 
Thanks for the invitation to come to visit you. I plan to do so one of these days. Right now I'm busy catching up. I hope you get back to your classes. I saw your name in a recent Columbia College brochure sent to me. I showed it to my senior class. 
Sincerely, 
Ed Bruell

February 12, 1964
Dear Jack,

   It's Lincoln's Birthday, and we're out of school in Illinois by state law.  In Hammond, Indiana, the banks are open, stamps may be purchased, and the mail goes through.  I often think of and tell the students of Lincoln's failures, and I take occasion to stress the old-fashioned virtues of hard work, ambition, and industry as opposed to being gifted and creating a Madison Avenue image.  I fear that Abe would have a rough time on modern T.V.  Besides he wasn't a multi-millionaire, and campaigns are expensive.
  I've just had an article in The English

(2
Record, from State University College, Plattsburgh, N.Y.  I'll send you a copy when I get mine back from the top brass.

  I'll try to catch the show Sunday at 7 over WMAQ.  I'm a faithful televiewer for my friends.  I was up Saturday at 7:45 listening to Rollin Poole on Harry Hoppels show.  It was titled "The Useful Monster" (IBM.)  I told him I hadn't yet figured out which one of those fellows was supposed to be the MONSTER.  It's odd that Misch Kohn didn't appear.  Maybe he was contemplating the Francis Bacon exhibit to make it out.
  Thanks for the tip on Quadrangle.  I'm following it up today and mentioning you, for which again thanks

File:Sketch of two birds
(3

  I'm so busy now.  Going for twenty years, almost, of married life with nothing but one confinement for my wife's pregnancy, we've avoided hospitals, as those who want justice avoid law courts.   Then in eight months we've had three trips - two for my wife.  Hers was in January, and she still has to return for treatments.  Thus, my writing suffers.
   I hope your book does well across the counter.  You surely told the ruth about the impact of the sales department on the editorial department.  Characteristically, letters about the book sing a

(4
soft song of praise and then lament with jeremiads about the cash register.

   You're surely a busy man, trying to keep up with  your writing and your teaching.  Your problem in getting The Disinherited published reminds me of Faulkner's The Sound and the Fury.   He had twelve rejections before the thirteenth publisher accepted it.  Doctors aren't the only ones that make mistakes apparently.
  I hope we can get together one day.

Sincerely
Ed Brunell
